channel.title: ASF Jira
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [LOG4J2-1548] [CronTriggeringPolicy] ConfigurationScheduler schedules the task infinitely after first fire
item.description:
After first fire at fixed time, rename/archive action is sheduled infinitely.

Example of configuration:

<RollingFile name="RollingFile"
    	 fileName="target/rolling-cron-once-a-day/rollingtest.log"
    	 filePattern="target/rolling-cron-once-a-day/rollingtest-%d{yyyyMMdd}_%d{HHmmss}-%i.log.gz"
    	 immediateFlush="true">
      <PatternLayout pattern="%d %p %C{1.} [%t] %m%n" />
      <CronTriggeringPolicy schedule="27 58 13 * * ?"/>
    </RollingFile>

First trigger is scheduled at 13:58:27 then every new log entry generates an archive file.

Test case and suggested fix attached.
item.summary: [CronTriggeringPolicy] ConfigurationScheduler schedules the task infinitely after first fire

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment: Test case.
Suggested fix.

Hello Pierrick,

I am testing the patch locally BUT I am not applying this part which does not seem to be needed to make the test pass:

diff --git a/log4j-core/src/main/java/org/apache/logging/log4j/core/config/plugins/util/ResolverUtil.java b/log4j-core/src/main/java/org/apache/logging/log4j/core/config/plugins/util/ResolverUtil.java
index 14bf1e8..898b321 100644
--- a/log4j-core/src/main/java/org/apache/logging/log4j/core/config/plugins/util/ResolverUtil.java
+++ b/log4j-core/src/main/java/org/apache/logging/log4j/core/config/plugins/util/ResolverUtil.java
@@ -201,7 +201,11 @@ public class ResolverUtil {
                 } else if (VFS.equals(url.getProtocol())) {
                     final String path = urlPath.substring(1, urlPath.length() - packageName.length() - 2);
                     final File file = new File(path);
-                    loadImplementationsInJar(test, packageName, file);
+                    if (file.isDirectory()) {
+                        loadImplementationsInDirectory(test, null, file);
+                    } else {
+                        loadImplementationsInJar(test, packageName, file);
+                    }
                 } else if (BUNDLE_RESOURCE.equals(url.getProtocol())) {
                     loadImplementationsInBundle(test, packageName);
                 } else {

Please create a separate ticket and test if possible.
I agree that it is unrelated. Logically though, it does make sense.

Pierrick,

Patch applied mod ResolverUtil changes.

We need a better unit test that does not take 60 seconds to run. Is that something you can take a look at?

Thank you and keep' em coming!

Gary

Done.
Added a constant RollingAppenderCronOnceADayTest.CRON_DELAY set to 10 seconds (instead of 45s previously).
Checked that test still failed in this condition with previous revision of ConfigurationScheduler.CronRunnable.run().
Test is run in 18s on my environment and cron rename action is scheduled.
Need to be checked within integration build.

phymbert,

Patch applied, thank you and keep' em coming!

Gary

Please verify and close.

Gary
garydgregory I have added a small fix in the test to clean working folder after execution.

I applied the patch https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/attachment/12825955/LOG4J2-1548-testcase-cleanFoldersRule.patch

Thank you!
Gary

@garydgregory:
This is an extremely serious bug that prevents us from using 2.6.2 in production. However, there have been bug fixes in 2.6.2, that we definitely rely upon.

Is there any chance that you could release v2.6.3 shortly with this bug fixed? Otherwise we'd have to patch it internally, which we'd really like to avoid.
It is very likely the 2.7 release will occur within a week or two.

Thanks, Ralph. However, we'd much rather prefer a 2.6.3 fix instead of a new minor version update, as we've had bad experiences with minor updates before. Is there no chance to release a patch-level update, too?
Can you elaborate a bit on which bad experiences you have had with minor updates?

I'd have to digest deeper for detailed information, but what I remember is:

  • an interface was changed between two minor releases
  • a memory bug was introduced (I'm not 100% sure though, if this was a minor release or even a patch level release).

In general, though, updating to a version with lots of changes is always risky. All we currently want is a fix for an urgent problem without introducing any new potential problems.

Yes, change is risk and lots of changes compound the risk.

From my POV, we are headed to 2.7 quick as Ralph mentioned. Anything beyond that like a 2.6.3 release with a single change is up to a volunteer release manager to step up and do. Since we are all volunteers here with limited time, it is unlikely to happen. Our release process is not lightweight. This is where we can wander into the grey area consulting services, which means paid development. I'm not sure how that works at Apache WRT ethics, the Apache Way, CoC, and I'm not sure what else. Personally, I'd rather go play tag with my son unless I can make an extra buck to buy him a surfboard

Gary

Thanks for your comment, Gary! A perfect valid view IMO.

Unfortunately I have no idea how the release management for Log4j2 works, and which requirements must be fulfilled for a volunteer to do that job - so I guess we'll in fact have to wait for v2.7 and hope that it won't introduce any new problems.
Do consider providing patches, testing the current code (Git master), and chiming in on the dev and use MLs. The more you put in, the more you'll get out IMO.

Stefan's point is valid too. If we weren't so close to cutting 2.7 I would consider making the 2.6.3 release with just a few patches.

But perhaps we should consider making some changes to our process. Instead of always working on dev we might want to cut a branch at every minor release and do the bug fixes there (as well as dev) so that we can provide a bit more stability. Let's face it, the changes in 2.6.x were fairly destabilizing.
I think we should consider making a public beta before releasing 2.7, to try to avoid introducing too many new problems.

Yes, using branches per minor version would really help. We do that at our company, and that's why for us releasing a patch for a minor version is just a matter of minutes - including the publishing of the Changelogs, etc.

Gary, as far as I understood there already was a pull request or a patch for this specific bug?

I don't know what you mean by "use MLs". Sorry, I'm not great at memorizing abbreviations.

MLs = mailing lists.

http://logging.apache.org/log4j/2.x/mail-lists.html

I'm okay with changing the process but we need to think through the implications of maintaining multiple branches. I don't mind fixing a bug in, say, the 2.7.x maintenance branch and merging that fix also into the 2.8 new features branch, but what do we do with subsequent releases?

Once we are on version 2.10, and we receive a bug report against version 2.7, do we add a fix to the maintenance branches 2.7.x, 2.8.x and 2.9.x in addition to the 2.10 new feature branch? When do we stop supporting old maintenance branches?
Maybe we should take this discussion on the log4j-dev mailing list, since it is not really related to this issue any more?

Thanks, Mikael!

@remkop@yahoo.com:
That's indeed an interesting topic. At our company we usually provide patch releases for older minor releases, if they have explicitly been requested. But that's relatively easy to manage for an in-house platform. For a public project like Log4j2 it's certainly more complicated.

I think blocker bugs should always be fixed in at least the latest 2 minor releases. Minor fixes should at least be applied to the previous release, too.

Hello SteffenO,

The fix is to be applied in ConfigurationScheduler and has been merged to master:
https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/attachment/12825255/LOG4J2-1548.patch

Others patch file attached are related to unit tests.

Cheers

I just forked Log4j2, created a new branch called release-2.6.x, updated all versions in the pom.xml to 2.6.3-SNAPSHOT, and applied the patches. I had to omit one part related to ResolverUtil.java, as that file has changed in the current master-Branch, but that did not affect the test cases, i.e. all Log4j2 test cases ran successfully:

https://github.com/sofax/logging-log4j2.git

(even though it took ages )
